title: Can you use 30 seconds of a copyrighted song? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you are a radio station broadcasting with the standard broadcaster’s license then you can broadcast songs of any duration. With this license you just pay a monthly fee and then make a record EVERY song you play and how many times you play them. The royalties are distributed to these recording artists based on how many plays they got. But you don’t have to record songs you played less than 30 seconds of. These artists don’t get paid. It is this industrial standard that leads to the general public thinking that they too can use 30 seconds of a song for free. But they can’t. And it isn’t really “for free” to have the right to do this either, since you are paying your monthly license fee whether you do this or not. Nothing about the radio license affects any other use. You cannot put 15 seconds of a song into a YouTube video, you cannot broadcast 25 seconds of a song on your late night TV show, you cannot perform this song on a stage (unless that stage has a paid “performance license”).

Can you? Yes. Is it legal? Only if you have permission. US radio stations can use short clips from songs without having to pay a royalty. This isn’t because of any law, though: it’s because their contracts with the US agencies that collect song royalties say they can. In other words, they have permission to do so, via those contracts. Unfortunately, a lot of people have heard that radio stations can use a few seconds of a song without having to pay a royalty, and not heard or not understood that this is because of their contracts. They’ve come up with the misinterpretations that (1) there’s a law that allows this (you’ll sometimes see “the Fair Use Act” mentioned; there is no such thing, Fair Use is part of the Copyright Act) and that (2) this applies to anyone. And then, of course, since specific rumors tend to survive better than general ones, people come up with various numbers of seconds and attach them. So, no. The idea that there’s a certain number of seconds that anyone can use of any song is an urban legend. In actual court cases, people have been found to have committed copyright infringement for using as little as three notes of a particular song.

Oh sure. My videos all consist of copyrighted music. The money for views goes to the copyright holder; not me. Some songs will be blocked, meaning you can’t post it. A copyright claim is not a problem. You cannot ever monetize a music video you don’t own or license. However 20 seconds could be fair use, depending no how it’s used. I would upload it and see what happens. It’s it’s blocked, make it private. You can still share it with up to 25 people.

You cannot use any amount of someone else’s copyrighted music without their permission, except for fair use purposes such as criticism, news reporting, research and education. Even then, a judge in a copyright infringement lawsuit would look at how substantial of an excerpt that 20 seconds is, and what impact your use has on the music’s potential market.
No. Not without getting permission or a license. You can’t even use one second, such as a sample, without getting permission.
Only if you have permission to do so.
